clinical_study.brief_title: Using an Online Patient Monitoring System to Improve Care for Children With Chronic Conditions
clinical_study.official_title: Integrated Clinical Information Sharing System: Implementation and Mixed-Methods Evaluation of a Web-based Monitoring and Management System for Patients With Chronic Conditions

brief_summary.textblock: The Integrated Clinical Information Sharing System (ICISS) is an online system designed to make it easy for healthcare providers to monitor patients' disease symptoms and functioning over time and in between in-person visits (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VR1vcbx0Ef4). Using combined quality improvement and randomized clinical trial methods, we will evaluate the impact of ICISS on the health outcomes, patient/family experience of care, and healthcare utilization for children and adolescents with ADHD, asthma, autism, depression, and epilepsy.

detailed_description.textblock:
The Integrated Clinical Information Sharing System (ICISS) is a web-based patient management and monitoring system designed to track patients' disease symptoms and response to therapy over time. ICISS enables clinics to use electronic surveys to gather data remotely from multiple responders, including patients, parents/guardians, school personnel and ancillary providers, and view the responses in a timely manner via graphical, tabular, and narrative summary formats.
This quality improvement (QI) initiative will implement ICISS as the standard of care for all patients who receive care for ADHD, asthma, autism, depression, and epilepsy within seven ambulatory specialties at Boston Children's Hospital. Patients and families will use ICISS to report on patient health status and will complete clinically-relevant questionnaires at routine intervals. Providers will use the information collected through ICISS to inform their clinical care of the patient/family.
To evaluate the effectiveness of ICISS, we will conduct a 24-month phased, cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) where we randomize providers to "active" vs. "delayed-start" to ICISS use, with patients clustered by provider (within specialties) for analytic purposes. Delayed-start providers will crossover to active ICISS use after 12 months. Patients/families will complete additional surveys in order to assess the system's actual or potential effects on patient/family-provider interactions, healthcare utilization and costs.

primary_outcome.description: Caregiver-reported ratings on disease-specific symptom rating scale. For example, Vanderbilt ADHD Parent Rating Scale for ADHD; Asthma Control Test for asthma

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients with "red flag" alerts
secondary_outcome.description: Number of patients whose responses to clinical questionnaires trigger a "red flag" alert in ICISS
Caregiver ratings on modified Clinical Global Assessment Scale

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and after every ambulatory visit for up to 84 months
secondary_outcome.description: Participant ratings on Post-Visit Experience of Care Survey

other_outcome.description: inpatient and ambulatory visits within healthcare system directly related to patient's medical or mental health condition
Out of pocket expenditures directly related to care for child's medical or mental health condition, e.g. co-pays, prescription costs

arm_group.description: Provider using ICISS for clinical care
Providers not using ICISS for clinical care

intervention.description: Use ICISS disease modules to manage patients

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pediatric patients with clinical diagnosis of ADHD, asthma, autism, depression, and/or epilepsy
- Patient receives care for these diagnoses from providers in participating ambulatory clinics (Primary Care, Adolescent Medicine, Developmental Medicine, Neurology, Psychiatry)
- Patient's primary caregiver enrolled in ICISS
Exclusion Criteria:
- None
